title: CBA and KPMG partner face fresh class action
text:
Plaintiff law firm Maurice Blackburn has filed a class action litigation suit in the Federal Court of Australia against the Commonwealth Bank's wealth management arm Colonial First State and former director Linda Elkins.

The suit seeks damages on behalf of "thousands of MySuper account holders" who allegedly sustained substantial losses as a result of breaches of super trustee duties by CFS, the trustee of the FirstChoice Superannuation Trust.

Linda Elkins has been named in a class action lawsuit filed in the Federal Court of Victoria. AAP

Maurice Blackburn lawyers will argue that failure to transition $3.2 billion of accrued default amounts (ADAs) of account holders in CFS's FirstChoice Employer Super fund to a "lower cost, higher performing MySuper product in a timely" way reflects a contravention of superannuation trustee obligations.

"Colonial had a legal obligation over and above a basic moral obligation to move default member balances into MySuper at the time that best met their members' needs, not their own," said Maurice Blackburn principal lawyer Miranda Nagy.

"The whole point of the MySuper reforms was to make sure that millions of everyday Australians who hadn't made an active decision about their super, were not 'getting charged for valet parking when they were taking the train', as [former financial services] minister [Bill] Shorten said at the time."
description: The Commonwealth Bank and former Colonial First State executive Linda Elkins face a new class action lawsuit over alleged breaches of super trustee duties.
